ygData.subject: Re: [gladiator] Gladiator specs, Part 1
ygData.msgSnippet: Wow. Thanks for the info, dph. And a big thanks to Tom, for providing the documentation. I m using scen300.fss as my template for analysis, since it s v8

Subject: Re: [gladiator] Gladiator specs, Part 1

From: "George \"Cookie\" Phillips" <cookie@...>

Wow. Thanks for the info, dph.

And a big thanks to Tom, for providing the documentation.

I'm using scen300.fss as my template for analysis, since it's v8 already.

Watch out for big-endian/little-endian problems if you're used to one or the other.. it took me quite a while to figure out why nothing matched up quite the way I thought it would. ^^;

<snip>
>    // 1-byte version #
This is 0x08 (08h) not '8' in ASCII. We don't need backwords compatability in this editor, do we? He offered a work-around anyways.

Most scenarios will need converted up to v8. Scenario 1, 2, 3, etc... are all v6. Some of them are even v5.

I wonder which version began using v8 maps...

>    // 8-byte string = grid name to load
This apparently has something to do with the internal name of the file;
"SCEN0000", "SCEN0030", etc..

It doesn't seem to be *that* important, and could probably default to the filename (assuming it's 8.3)

>    // 30-byte scenario title (ver 6+)

Standard C String -- null terminated, then padded with garbage to get to the 30th byte.

>    // 1-byte char = scenario type, default is 0

I guess non-0 is for deathmatch. I'm not gonna bother looking (mainly 'cause I dunno where the DM levels are stored. ;))

Actually, when I converted scen1.fss to v8, it came up with a '1' rather than a '0'. Odd.

>    // 2-bytes par-value, v.8+

How fast you're supposed to complete the level, in hex, it seems. Unsigned, too.

>    // 2-bytes (short) = total objects to follow

unsigned, or signed? I doubt anyone's map would even begin to approach THAT many objects... but nonetheless it's a possibility.

>    // List of n objects, each of 7-bytes of form:
>           // 1-byte ORDER
>           // 1-byte FAMILY

ORDER of 0 seems to be a character (either friend or foe):
because ORDER 0x00 FAMILY 0x00 is a warrior.. and ORDER 0x00 FAMILY 0x02 is an archer..

>           // 2-byte short xpos
>           // 2-byte short ypos
You said you could make new map-sizes by making blank .pix files and converting them to maps? How large are 'average' maps? Is this a pixel-by-pixel thing? Or is it a block-by-block thing?

>           // 1-byte TEAM

0x00 is red?
0x01 is blue?
0x02 is yellow?
0x03 is green?
0x04 is purple?

... those are just guesses. Maybe someone'll be able to figure something out.

>           // 1-byte facing
0x01 is north, going clockwise, maybe?
>           // 1-byte command
...It'd be nice to get a list of these, too...
>           // 1-byte level // 2 bytes in version 7+
>           // 12-bytes name
Named characters appear in the status window when they die.. thus, it's probably best if most characters have 0x00 for their first letter of their name and then gibberish for the rest (standard C string)

>           // 10 bytes reserved
In every map, I think it's always "MSTRMSTRMS".. but since it's reserved (ie; unused) I doubt it'll matter if that gets changed.

>    // 1-byte # of lines of text to load
>    // List of n lines of text, each of form:
>           // 1-byte character width of line
>           // m bytes == characters on this line

Simple enough to figure out.

Anyone else have any programming thoughts on the matter?

-George "Cookie" Phillips

Co-Editor-In-Chief
